title: Unique Patterns in Amino Acid Sequences of Aging‐Related Proteins
authors: Eszter Zita Szatmári; Attila Csordás; Csaba Kerepesi
abstract: Abstract Aging has strong genetic components and the list of genes that may regulate the aging process is collected in the GenAge database. There may be characteristic patterns in the amino acid sequences of aging‐related proteins that distinguish them from other proteins and this information will lead to a better understanding of the aging process. To test this hypothesis, human protein sequences are extracted from the UniProt database and the relative frequency of every amino acid residue in aging‐related proteins and the remaining proteins is calculated. The main observation is that the mean relative frequency of aspartic acid (D) is consistently higher, while the mean relative frequencies of tryptophan (W) and leucine (L) are consistently lower in aging‐related proteins compared to the non‐aging‐related proteins for the human and four examined model organisms. It is also observed that the mean relative frequency of aspartic acid is higher, while the mean relative frequency of tryptophan is lower in pro‐longevity proteins compared to anti‐longevity proteins in model organisms. Finally, it is found that aging‐related proteins tend to be longer than non‐aging‐related proteins. It is hoped that this analysis initiates further computational and experimental research to explore the underlying mechanisms of these findings.

title: Identification of Surface Markers and Functional Characterization of Myeloid Derived Suppressor Cell‐Like Adherent Cells
authors: John Clyde Co Soriano; Shiho Tsutsumi; Daiya Ohara; Keiji Hirota; Gen Kondoh; Tatsuya Niwa; Hideki Taguchi; Tetsuya Kadonosono; Shinae Kizaka‐Kondoh
abstract: Abstract Myeloid‐derived suppressor cell (MDSC)‐like adherent cells (MLACs) are a recently identified CD11b + F4/80 − myeloid cell subset that can infiltrate tumors early in development and promote their growth. Because of these functions, MLACs play an important role in establishing an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME). However, the lack of MLAC‐specific markers has hampered further characterization of this cell type. This study identifies the gene signature of MLACs by analyzing RNA‐sequencing (RNA‐seq) and public single‐cell RNA‐seq data, revealing that MLACs are an independent cell population that are distinct from other intratumoral myeloid cells. After combining proteome analysis of membrane proteins with RNA‐seq data, H2‐Ab1 and CD11c are indicated as marker proteins that can support the isolation of MLAC subsets from CD11b + F4/80 − myeloid cells by fluorescence‐activated cell sorting. The CD11b + F4/80 − H2‐Ab1 + and CD11b + F4/80 − CD11c + MLAC subsets represent approximately half of the MLAC population that is isolated based on their adhesion properties and possess gene signatures and functional properties similar to those of the MLAC population. Additionally, membrane proteome analysis suggests that MLACs express highly heterogeneous surface proteins. This study facilitates an integrated understanding of heterogeneous intratumoral myeloid cells, as well as the molecular and cellular details of the development of an immunosuppressive TME.

title: An Ex Vivo Aorta Culture Model to Study Vascular Cellular Senescence
authors: Yijie Yu; Shihui Bian; Yu Jiang; Bo Li; Xinggang Cui; Shu Ding; Zhiyin Dai; Rui Chen; Wei Zhong; Wei Yuan
abstract: Abstract Animal studies on vascular aging pose a few limitations. One of the most important reasons for this is the absence of a fast and efficient model of vascular tissue aging. In this study, ex vivo aortic culture and Matrigel subcutaneous implantation are combined to develop a new model for studying vascular cellular senescence. Eight‐week‐old C57BL/6J mice are used to obtain aortas. Bleomycin is used to induce aortas senescence in vitro. Then, aortas are transplanted to the acceptor mice with Matrigel. Senescence is evaluated using western blotting, quantitative polymerase chain reaction, and senescence‐associated beta‐galactosidase activity. Inflammatory cytokines are detected using Luminex Liquid Suspension Chip. RNA levels are analyzed by transcriptome sequencing. The results revealed that vessels in the bleomycin group exhibited significant senescence than those in the control group that can be enhanced by stripping vessel adventitia. The levels of cytokines such as interleukin (IL‐2, IL‐1β, and IL‐6 increased significantly in the ex vivo model. Furthermore, transcriptome sequencing revealed 56 significantly differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in ex vivo model vessels compared with those in naturally aging aortas. In conclusion, this study introduces a cost‐effective and time‐saving vessel senescence model for vascular cellular senescence.

title: Unraveling Exogenous DNA Processing in Cas4‐Lacking Crispr Systems: A Novel Bypass Pathway Explored
authors: Xinming Su; Qi Xiao; Zehua Wang; Shiwei Duan
abstract: Abstract Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)/CRISPR‐associated (Cas) systems are widely distributed adaptive immune systems found in prokaryotes. The process involves three main stages: adaptation, expression, and interference. While the adaptation stage has been extensively studied, there is still an incomplete understanding of the mechanisms underlying the capture, trimming, and integration of exogenous DNA. For instance, Cas4, a CRISPR‐Cas protein with endonuclease activity, is responsible for selecting and processing protospacer adjacent motif (PAM) sequences. However, some CRISPR isoforms lack Cas4 activity, relying on other enzymes for adaptive immunity. Recently, Wang et al. presented a novel model of exogenous DNA processing in a type I‐E CRISPR system lacking Cas4 in a Nature article. This model integrates protospacer processing into CRISPR arrays through fine‐tuned synthases formed by DnaQ‐like exonuclease (DEDDh) and Cas1‐Cas2 complexes. Their study introduces a novel model, shedding new light on the evolution of CRISPR adaptive immunity. This perspective comprehensively examines the fundamental process of CRISPR adaptive immunity, detailing both the classical pathway mediated by Cas4 and the alternative pathway mediated by DEDDh. Furthermore, a thorough evaluation of Wang et al.’s work is conducted, highlighting its strengths, weaknesses, and existing research challenges.

title: Editorial on “Genetics And Metabolic Diseases” Special Issue
authors: Mario Luca Morieri; Hongwen Zhou
abstract: Obesity and diabetes are common and complex metabolic diseases, with an increasing prevalence worldwide that results from the interplay of genetic and environmental factors. Recent advances in “-omic” technologies have enabled the discovery of an increasing number of genetic, epigenetic and metabolite markers associated with these conditions. These findings have revealed the complex pathophysiology of these conditions. The challenge now is for researchers and physicians to translate this growing knowledge into action and new clinical approaches. The motivation for this special issue was to provide perspectives and tools to improve risk prediction, prevention, and treatment of metabolic diseases, to better care for patients. In this special issue of Advanced Biology, “Genetics and Metabolic Diseases”, we highlight articles with a translational approach, moving from laboratory discoveries to clinical translation, with an emphasis on metabolic diseases resulting from genetic mutations, such as monogenic obesity and lipodystrophy. Other studies dissect the interrelationship between obesity, diabetes, and lipid metabolism to improve prediction and managed care of complications arising from treatment. In the study by Di Paola et al. (adbi.202200319), the authors address the strict relationship between obesity, diabetes, and dyslipidemia, focusing on the evaluation of how polypeptide N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferase 2 (coded by GALNT2) influence HDL-c and triglycerides levels. While GALNT2 can influence lipid metabolism (e.g., angiopoietin like 3 , apolipoprotein C-IIII and phospolipid transfer protein ) it also affects insulin sensitivity and adipokines. The authors use genetic variants to evaluate the hypothesis that GALNT2 effects on circulating lipoprotein levels go beyond the sole regulation of key lipid metabolism enzyme and also includes effects on insulin sensitivity. In the review by Wang and colleagues (adbi.202300035), a detailed overview is given of the central and peripheral roles of melanocortin 4 receptor (MC4R) in energy metabolism and endocrine hormone homeostasis. Evidence supports the diversity of phenotypes and biased downstream signaling caused by distinct MC4R mutations. This review also includes recent advances in drug development targeting MC4R. MC4R was also evaluated by Zhou et al. (adbi.202300007), reporting six MC4R variants (Y35C, T53I, V103I, R165W, G233S, and C277X) in morbidly obese persons in China. In this morbidly obese cohort, patients with rare MC4R variants seems to benefit the most from metabolic surgery. With the global epidemic of obesity, there is a growing number of patients who need to undergo bariatric/metabolic surgery. In this context, the study by Centeno et al. (adbi.202300001) evaluated the epigenetic changes following bariatric surgery. Specifically, the authors evaluated the DNA methylation remodeling in adipose tissue and identified changes in more than one thousand CpG sites. The GNAS complex locus which is associated with BMI, lipid obesity, and glucose metabolism, harbored the sites with the greatest changes. Remarkably, several of the other sites identified in the study are in genes/loci previously not known to be related to metabolic disorders, stimulating future studies. This study also underscores the role that epigenetic regulation might play in modulating adipose tissue function in obese patients and how these altered functions may potentially be reversed. Excessive fat accumulation also affects the liver and Xue and colleagues (adbi.202200150) described their results inhibiting geranylgeranyl diphosphate synthase (GGPPS) as a novel strategy for treating metabolic associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD). Using a structure-based virtual small molecule screening method, 4-AZ is detected as a GGPPS targeted inhibitor. Further investigation showed that 4-AZ promotes the degradation of GGPPS via the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway and inhibits the accumulation of lipids in primary hepatocytes and decreased lipogenic gene expression through GGPPS. Yu and colleagues (adbi.202200301) identify four unique lamin A/C (LMNA) mutations from six lipodystrophy patients and show how these LMNA variations are characterized by decreased Lamin A/C stability and degradation primarily through the ubiquitin-proteasome system. Ma and colleagues (adbi.202200234) provide a narrative review of the key redox factors, endogenous mechanisms for redox homeostasis, and advanced techniques for dynamic monitoring of redox states. Liu and colleagues (adbi.202300100) discuss the role of diet and gut microbiota interactions on metabolic homeostasis. In addition, they review the alterations of gut microbiota in relation to diet. They emphasize the potential for diet-microbiota crosstalk to influence metabolic homeostasis. One important aspect in the care of patients with metabolic disease is the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular complications. Liu and colleagues (adbi.202200130) demonstrate the therapeutic effects of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) on human diabetic cardiomyocytes (DCMs) and establish a novel DCM model for mechanistic based studies. Based on human induced pluripotent stem cells-derived cardiomyocytes, they highlight that both GLP-1 7–36 and GLP-1 9–36 restore cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and abnormal calcium transient frequency. Specifically, that possible targets of GLP-1 7–36 are involved in the regulation of mitotic nuclear division and extracellular matrix-receptor interaction, while targets of GLP-1 9–36 influence kinetochore assembly, complement, and coagulation cascades. Pipino et al. (adbi.202300172) review prediction of cardiovascular disease – a major complication of metabolic disease, – with a focus on how epigenetic and metabolomic markers may predict endothelial dysfunction in type 2 diabetes. Excitingly, the manuscript describes the epigenetic-metabolite relationship and how these can provide novel insights into the physio-pathological processes in early stages of endothelium function. Understanding these processes will enable identification of disease biomarkers and therapies to reduce the cardiovascular burden in metabolic disease. In the review by Geiger et al. (adbi.202300211), details are provided on various epigenetic changes, such as DNA methylation, histone modification, and noncoding RNA, and how they affect immuno-metabolic disease conditions. The authors also describe several environmental factors that influence the epigenetic signature and how these can be transmitted trans-generationally, i.e., influencing the disease traits of the patients and their offspring. The review discusses metabolic traits, such as insulin resistance, systemic inflammation, macrophage polarization, endothelial dysfunction, metabolic cardiomyopathy, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. In addition, the review describes currently used drugs (e.g., statins and metformin) as “epigenetic” drugs, suggesting their mechanism of action may be mediated by epigenetic changes. In summary, this special issue includes several studies that aim to advance knowledge and reduce the global burden of metabolic disease. The populations described in these manuscripts are diverse and derived from different countries with different ancestries. Such diversity will further enhance discovery and underscores the value in diverse and equitable approaches in future studies. The care of all patients, recognizing genetic and environmental differences, needs to be considered if we are to be successful in mitigating metabolic diseases worldwide. This editorial was originally intended to be published in volume 7 issue 9, but due to an error in production was not included. To read the complete issue in its intended form please refer to this virtual issue. title: Pitstop‐2 Upsets The Integrity of Nuclear Pore Complexes (NPCs) by Interaction with β‐Propeller Folds of Npc Scaffold Proteins
authors: Sílvio Terra Stefanello; Caren Rigon Mizdal; Victor Shahin
abstract: Abstract The small compound Pitstop‐2 is a recent potent inhibitor of clathrin‐mediated endocytosis (CME), widely used in biomedical research areas. In recent years, however, it is observed that it exhibits CME‐independent inhibitory effects on nuclear pore complexes (NPCs), the nucleocytoplasmic gatekeepers. NPCs are elaborate proteinaceous transport nano‐machineries of crucial physiological importance rendering them novel targets for various medical applications. They mediate all nucleocytoplasmic transport forming a physiologically essential selective nucleocytoplasmic barrier. The direct Pitstop‐2 disruptive effects on NPCs manifested themselves at both the structural and functional integrity levels. Moreover, they are massive, acute, and detectable at concentrations equal to CME‐inhibitory concentrations. Pitstop‐2 inhibits CME by binding to the terminal β‐propeller domain of the heavy chain of clathrin. Several NPC scaffold proteins, critical for the structural and functional integrity of the NPC, possess β‐propeller folds. Herein, utilizing computational docking analysis, it is demonstrated that Pitstop‐2 exhibits particularly high binding affinities to β‐propeller folds of NPC scaffold proteins, similar to its binding affinity to the terminal β‐propeller domain of clathrin. The authors, therefore, conclude that Pitstop‐2 is a potent disruptor of NPCs, an activity which, separately or in synergy with CME inhibition, may be exploited for a myriad of pharmacological applications.

title: The Effect of Parent Cell Type on Small Extracellular Vesicle‐Derived Vehicle Functionality
authors: Sruti Bheri; Hyun‐Ji Park; Jessica R. Hoffman; Felipe Takaesu; Michael Davis
abstract: Abstract Cell therapies involving c‐kit+ progenitor cells (CPCs) and mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have been actively studied for cardiac repair. The benefits of such therapies have more recently been attributed to the release of small extracellular vesicles (sEVs) from the parent cells. These sEVs are 30−180 nm vesicles containing protein/nucleic acid cargo encapsulated within an amphiphilic bilayer membrane. Despite their pro‐reparative effects, sEV composition and cargo loading is highly variable, making it challenging to develop robust therapies with sEVs. Synthetic alternatives have been developed to allow cargo modulation, including prior work from the laboratory, to design sEV‐like vehicles (ELVs). ELVs are synthesized from the sEV membrane but allow controlled cargo loading. It is previously shown that loading pro‐angiogenic miR‐126 into CPC‐derived ELVs significantly increases endothelial cell angiogenesis compared to CPC‐sEVs alone. Here, they expand on this work to design MSC‐derived ELVs and study the role of the parent cell type on ELV composition and function. It is found that ELV origin does affect the ELV potency and that ELV membrane composition can affect outcomes. This study showcases the versatility of ELVs to be synthesized from different parent cells and highlights the importance of selecting ELV source cells based on the desired functional outcomes.

title: Caffeine‐reinforced Collagen as Localized Microenvironmental Trans‐Browning Bio‐Matrix for Soft Tissue Repair and Regeneration in Bariatric Condition
authors: Sreelekshmi Sreekumar; Vinu Vijayan; K. P. Gangaraj; Menakha Thangasornaraja; Manikantan Syamala Kiran
abstract: Abstract The wound exudates, hypoperfusion of the subcutaneous fat layer, and poor vasculature worsen wound management in obese subjects. In the current study, a multifunctional Caffeine‐reinforced collagen biomaterial is developed that can simultaneously modulate lipid metabolism and angiogenesis in obese wound microenvironments for faster tissue regeneration. The biomaterial is fabricated specialized for obese conditions to initiate simultaneous lipolysis and angiogenesis locally in the hypoxic subcutaneous fat in wound margins of obese subjects. Caffeine‐reinforced collagen biomatrix shows better structural integrity, thermal stability, bio‐compatibility, and lesser proteolytic susceptibility. Caffeine‐collagen biomaterial promote angiogenesis, fibroblast migration, and localized browning of white adipocytes to activate thermogenesis in the subcutaneous fat layer at the wound site. Full‐thickness excision wound healing studies performed in obese C57BL6 mice shows faster wound closure within day 9 when compare to control mice. The Caffeine‐reinforced collagen biomaterial remodeled the wound site locally by activating fibroblast to secrete collagen, activate endothelial cells to promote angiogenesis, and induce browning in white adipocytes in subcutaneous fat. The study opens a new direction in bariatric tissue regenerative medicine by locally modulating lipid metabolism, angiogenesis, and trans‐browning at the injured site for faster complete restoration of the damaged tissue.

title: Advancing Advanced Biology. A Letter from the Editor
authors: Monty Montano
abstract: With the beginning of each new year, we tend to ask ourselves, what has changed and where do we fit within a renewing landscape of possibility? In the life sciences, there have been profound changes, not only in the pace of discovery, but also in the culture of how we innovate. Scientific advances are outpacing traditionally defined research disciplines, and while we are achieving a deeper understanding within disciplines, there is a growing appreciation for cross-disciplinary insights that dissolve boundaries, creating fertile ground for emerging fields. The culture of how we innovate has also shifted towards collaborative teams, and increasingly with industry and international partnerships, collectively engaged in integrative, multi-modal approaches to meeting the next generation of challenges in the life sciences. I have the privilege of starting 2022 as the new Editor-in-Chief of Advanced Biology during a pivotal period of change, both in the approach and in the culture of scientific discovery. My hope is that Advanced Biology will sit at the intersection of this change, giving voice to emerging fields and providing a forum for the highest quality research in emerging life sciences. Advanced Biology is primed with a new expanded scope to meet the challenge of reporting cutting-edge research within and across life science disciplines. The journal provides the readership with a wide array of high-quality studies designed to provoke insight by juxtaposing multiple disciplines curated through rigorous peer-review. Evidence of the journal's upward trajectory is the newly assigned 2021 impact factor (4+), indicating a continuously increasing impact in life sciences publications. The continuing success of the journal would not have been possible without the talented and professional efforts by the previous editors, operating within the historic context of Wiley's Advanced series of integrated journals. With the help of deputy editors, our editorial board, and staff expertise accessible within the matrix of Advanced journals, our goal is to develop a publishing niche that builds connectivity across disciplines, between and within academia and industry, nationally and internationally, to catalyze discussion, innovation, and knowledge growth in the basic and applied biosciences. Advanced Biology will facilitate connectivity through soliciting and publishing interdisciplinary reviews, thematic series, and commentary on emerging trends by key thought leaders across the life sciences. The journal will, in turn, adapt content to provide timely publications with thematic issues and calls-for-papers, based on data-driven analysis of trends in research at the crossroads of existing and emerging life sciences. To demonstrate our commitment to cutting-edge research, from multiple perspectives, geographies, and life sciences backgrounds, we plan to invite early-stage investigators worldwide to consider joining our editorial board. Among the key deliverable goals for Advanced Biology will be to publish the best science within disciplines, and at the intersection of the life sciences (e.g., geriatrics and infectious diseases, immunology and the biology of aging), to provide peer-reviewed, holistic perspectives, from molecular to population-based studies (see our expanded Scope section here). Advanced Biology also plans to develop a suite of timely reviews and thematic issues reflecting cutting-edge life science research both in academia and industry and will feature conversations with key opinion leaders as horizon view assessments of how research is evolving. We have restructured the journal to meet these goals and in so doing, we hope to enable author cross-over exposure into emerging life sciences research, to overcome “silo” effects that often limit specialty journals, and to create a forum for innovation in cross-disciplinary research. On behalf of our talented team at Advanced Biology, I look forward to working with all stakeholders in the life sciences community, in a culture of collaboration and interdisciplinary and international perspectives, to meet the challenges of advancing scientific knowledge across the life sciences.

title: Emerging life sciences series: Q&A with the Editor
authors: Monty Montano
abstract: Tell us about your earlier research experiences. What drew you to the intersection of cancer and neuroscience research? After my first year of clinical residency in otolaryngology, I joined the lab of Dr. Ziv Gil. His lab was studying pancreatic cancer, one of the deadliest cancers. Interestingly, the lab was focused on the intersection between immune cells, nerves, and cancer cells. Pancreatic cancer, like other exocrine gland tumors (for example, prostate and salivary gland tumors), is highly innervated and has a unique feature: the ability to invade and disseminate along nerves. This feature, called perineural invasion, is an ominous sign and is actually the fourth route of metastasis, along with local invasion, lymphatic spread, and hematogenous spread. In perineural invasion, tumor cells use the nerves in the vicinity of the tumor as “highways” for distant spread. In patients, perineural invasion can cause pain and paralysis. Unfortunately, these “highways” often lead to critical structures such as the spine and brain, which limits our ability as surgeons to completely remove the tumors. Can you tell us about some key scientific developments that led to your current thinking about the tumor microenvironment, immune response and health outcomes? Throughout my training and as a junior faculty member, I was always amazed by the minimal (if any) role attributed to the nervous system in cancer. As a clinician, we consider nerves mainly in the context of pain, or we think about how invading tumors or cancer treatments damage nerves. However, considering that the nervous system controls every aspect of our life, in health and disease, it was peculiar that the role of nerves in regulating cancer growth, progression, and response to therapy was neglected for many years. The article that marked the change in the field, published by Claire Magnon et al. in Science in 2013,[1] showed for the first time that there is an orchestrated interaction between the autonomous nervous system and cancer development. This article left a strong impression on my mission as a scientist and led me to think about a fundamental question: how do nerves get to the tumor microenvironment? I realized that the process may be similar to angiogenesis in that a cascade of signals coming from cancer cells and maybe other cells in the tumor microenvironment might be involved. This led me to study paracrine signaling, but this time I was looking in the opposite direction from my view as a clinician—that is, at how cancer cells and nerves interact. During my Ph.D. studies, I obtained experience in dissecting paracrine signals, including vesicle-mediated signaling, that led to our findings about the ability of cancer to “hack” the nervous system. In your view, what are the pressing and longer-term questions at the interface of cancer and neuroscience and how should they be prioritized? What do you see as the major challenges in cancer neuroscience research, and future directions to overcome barriers? The major challenge is the overcoming of disciplinary barriers to conversations and collaboration between scientists in each field. There are many technical obstacles (for instance, cancer biologists usually do not understand neuron culture, andmany neuroscientists are not familiar with cancer models), but these challenges can be easily sorted out through discussions and data sharing. I had dual training, but it is not a necessity if you have good collaborators. How is cancer neuroscience a great example of opportunities for early-stage investigators to engage in interdisciplinary research? Engaging in interdisciplinary research is the essence of advancing the field of cancer neuroscience. Getting trained in both fields and becoming an expert in both is nearly impossible. I was fortunate to have great mentors who became my collaborators after my transition to independence. My mentors have expertise in fields that would have taken me a lifetime to acquire, including Dr. Jeffrey Myers in cancer modeling and P53 biology; Dr. George Calin in RNA biology; and Dr. Patrick Dougherty in neurobiology. Each of these mentors has dedicated his life to a specific topic, and taking advantage of what each one brings to the table has made it possible for all of us to make new discoveries. As the guest editor, what are your goals for the upcoming thematic issue on neuron-tumor interactions and how will you measure success? My goals are threefold: one, to introduce the field of cancer neuroscience to the readership of Advanced Biology and to expose neuroscientists, cancer biologists, and clinicians to the field; two, to foster discussion and collaboration between the disciplines; and three, to drive policymakers and key stakeholders, such as the National Institutes of Health, to invest in cancer neuroscience research since this is an unexplored territory that holds a lot of therapeutic potential for cancer patients and their caregivers. The most important and personally exciting deliverable for me would be to see more clinical trials looking at neuromodulation as cancer therapy. I think that until the first neuromodulatory approach or therapy targeting the nervous system is Food and Drug Administration/European Medicines Agency-approved for cancer, we will not be satisfied. But we are becoming more optimistic by the day. Moran Amit, MD PhD mamit@mdanderson.org Photo Credit: Photograph courtesy of Dr. Moran Amit.

authors: Thorsten Keller; Hermann Koepsell; Jürgen Gröll
abstract: Abstract The regulatory solute carrier protein, family 1, member 1 (RS1) modulates via its N‐terminal domain RS1‐reg the activity of Na + – d ‐glucose cotransporter 1 (SGLT1) and thereby the glucose uptake in the small intestine by blocking the release of SGLT1‐containing vesicles at the trans ‐Golgi network (TGN). The antidiabetic activity of RS1 is mediated by ornithindecarboxylase 1 (ODC1), catalyzing the conversion of ornithine to putrescine. Putrescine can bind to a buddying protein complex for SGLT1‐containing vesicles at the membrane of the TGN, triggering vesicle release. In this report, a first in‐depth analysis of the important binding process between ODC1 and RS1‐reg for regulating glucose uptake in the human organism is described by comparing results from the surface‐based methods, “surface plasmon resonance” (SPR) and “surface acoustic wave” (SAW) with findings by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC). In cases of SAW and SPR, three different assay surface setups are compared, resulting in small but significant differences in K D values for different surfaces. Noteworthy, an affinity increase by the factor of about 100 for the interaction is detected and herewith described for the first time in the presence of biological membranes that may be relevant in vivo for the biological function of RS1 and future bespoken antidiabetic drug development.

title: Changes of Mutations and Copy‐Number and Enhanced Cell Migration during Breast Tumorigenesis
authors: Seung Hyuk Lee; Joon Yup Kim; Peter Kim; Zhipeng Dong; Chia‐Yi Su; Eun Hyun Ahn
abstract: Abstract Although cancer stem cells (CSCs) play a major role in tumorigenesis and metastasis, the role of genetic alterations in invasiveness of CSCs is still unclear. Tumor microenvironment signals, such as extracellular matrix (ECM) composition, significantly influence cell behaviors. Unfortunately, these signals are often lost in in vitro cell culture. This study determines putative CSC populations, examines genetic changes during tumorigenesis of human breast epithelial stem cells, and investigates single‐cell migration properties on ECM‐mimetic platforms. Whole exome sequencing data indicate that tumorigenic cells have a higher somatic mutation burden than non‐tumorigenic cells, and that mutations exclusive to tumorigenic cells exhibit higher predictive deleterious scores. Tumorigenic cells exhibit distinct somatic copy number variations (CNVs) including gain of duplications in chromosomes 5 and 8. ECM‐mimetic topography selectively enhances migration speed of tumorigenic cells, but not of non‐tumorigenic cells, and results in a wide distribution of tumorigenic single‐cell migration speeds, suggesting heterogeneity in cellular sensing of contact guidance cues. This study identifies mutations and CNVs acquired during breast tumorigenesis, which can be associated with enhanced migration of breast tumorigenic cells, and demonstrates that a nanotopographically‐defined platform can be applied to recapitulate an ECM structure for investigating cellular migration in the simulated tumor microenvironment.

title: Notes on Surviving Head and Neck Cancer: Paving the Road Ahead
authors: Ed Steger; Brandi J. Mattson; Monty Montano
abstract: Survival rates for most head and neck cancers (HNCs) have seen large statistically significant improvements. This is attributed in part to recent advances in the use of chemotherapy plus radiation and the use of hyperfractionated radiotherapy.[1] That's great news on the survival front and can be attributed to the physicians and researchers who continue to evolve HNC research and treatment. However, on this journey as a survivor, sometimes it seems that with every step forward, obstacles appear. What follows are notes divided into two parts. The first explores agency and patient-centric actions under the patient's control that may lead to better survival outcomes. The second discusses quality of life (QoL) considerations for long term HNC survivors based on my experience. Part 1. Patient agency can drive better outcomes Knowledge and outreach were enabling. While each person and their cancer is a unique medical condition, there is a growing wealth of information to help better understand your cancer. I accumulated knowledge and found key informational resources about the latest treatment approaches, medical facilities treating high numbers of specific HNCs and clinical trials. After undergoing a difficult surgery, I was diagnosed with 5 inoperable hot spots, I asked my physician what options I had. Chemo left me in bed for a year but the 5 became 1 operable cancer spot. Having learned much, I was prepared when my physician told me that the cancer will keep coming back if we don't try something out-of-the-box. My reply – what options do I have? My daughter was growing but my job as her dad was not finished. The research empowered me. My physician and I had built a trusting relationship. He listened to me and I listened to him. I became a knowledgeable advocate for myself. I became a partner in my treatment plan. My medical team found a clinical trial at another highly regarded HNC institution and modeled my treatment plan based on that trial. I was fortunate that my persistence and having a care team that listened and fought with me. My cancer never returned. I remain thankful that I continue to see my daughter grow into the amazing person she is becoming. Throughout this journey of ups and downs, I found an extended support system through social media. There I received patient-centered insights for my questions and concerns. Every question I had I took to my physician. He still listens and discusses all the options facing me. Write down your questions before your visit with the medical team. Visits can be overwhelming and by writing the questions down there is a higher likelihood they will be asked and not forgotten. Also, find the right medical team for you. For me, it was pivotal. Establishing and maintaining follow up visits. Fifty to 60% of HNC patients develop a recurrence within 2 years after initial diagnosis and treatment.[2] Establish a follow up plan and stick to it. The visits may begin quarterly and then taper off to semi-annually, and then annually. At a minimum, maintaining follow up visits, is a quality-of-life (QoL) activity, because the earlier a recurrence is detected and attended to, the better the potential outcome and quality of life for you. Maintaining oral health and nutrition. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) is common among HNC survivors and can be challenging. Work with a qualified medical Speech Language Pathologist (SLP) to determine a nutrition plan. This may necessitate a modified diet or a feeding tube. Feeding tubes have their place in the HNC survivorship population. Research indicates that bacteria in the oral cavity (i.e., microbiome) can sometimes lead to systemic infection, and other health related challenges.[3, 4] This further complicates what can and cannot be done safely in a compromised jawbone due to radiation. An ounce of prevention is worth more than a pound of cure. Rehabilitation was essential. Speech and swallowing deficits are common HNC survivor outcomes. A qualified medical SLP will help guide you through rehabilitation. I recommend you start this process concurrent with your treatment. A common saying one will hear is, “use it or lose it”. This applies to both speech and swallowing. Finding my “new normal.” The experience of surviving HNC changes life after treatment. For example, because your voice changes, it may be more difficult for others to understand you. You may lose your ability to be spontaneous, and for me, I couldn't tell jokes as well as before. Jokes need timing to be most effective and, well, funny. With my speech difficulties, I couldn't deliver a good punch line – but I still try. I kept activities that were important to me in both phases of my life pre- and post-HNC. I traveled then for fun, now I travel to advocate for all those surviving HNCs and swallowing disorders. Because I don't have a social eating ability due to my surgery, my social activities are a bit different or at least require more thought as my diet has changed. I can't really go out to eat, in a literal sense. To be part of social dining experience, I may move the food around on the plate (like a little kid who doesn't want to eat his peas) so that the wait staff doesn't come over and ask, is everything alright with your meal? One's “new normal” may change over time. Whatever changes you face, understand there is a cost to survivorship and accept them. You are not giving up. You are continuing to fight with your dignity, awareness, knowledge and your treatment plan. Adapting to your new circumstances gives you power over what seems at times uncontrollable. Part II. Quality-of Life (QOL) as a survivor Post-traumatic stress. HNC treatment can be traumatic. I was convinced that I was suffocating when removed from the ventilator following my salvage surgery (Briefly, my salvage surgery involved removal of the primary tumor at the base of my tongue, my left lingual nerve ran right through my tumor necessitating the severing of that nerve. My left jawbone and 4 perfectly good teeth were surgically removed and replaced by my tibia bone from my right leg, a skin graft from my right upper thigh was used to repair the tissue from where my tibia was removed. A titanium plate was inserted from my earlobe to my chin to support my jaw's reconstruction. This was a 12-hour surgery). This sensation lasted on and off for 5 days. Recently, when the thought of how a COVID-19 infection could potentially affect my respiratory system, memories of suffocation came rushing back 14 years after the salvage surgery. Seek appropriate mental health support, because surviving HNC leaves a trail of tears in your mind and body, often resulting in some type of PTSD.[5] Aspiration pneumonia awareness. This is common among HNC survivors.[6] Onset can vary. Mine happened 5 years after my treatment stopped and I can pinpoint the moment it happened. Everyone aspirates, it's all a matter of degree, frequency, and your overall health. My aspiration pneumonia crept up on me to the point where I was very weak and became hospitalized. Social isolation and other changes. As mentioned earlier, speech and swallowing may become compromised. These were functions that I took for granted. Imagine not being able to eat or communicate verbally in social situations. This will change how you live your life and what you enjoy. I chose to recognize and accept with conviction this new reality, because just maybe, this bittersweet adversity might create opportunities to discover new joys. Swallowing Disorders (dysphagia). As the volunteer president of the National Foundation of Swallowing Disorders for over a decade I have a lot of contact with those experiencing dysphagia. Many are HNC survivors requiring validating diagnosis.[7] The number of times I've heard other patients say their healthcare provider says it is all in their head is disheartening. If you encounter this, and I hope you don't, challenge your medical team to recognize this is real and needs to be addressed. If not, find a new healthcare provider! Aging versus treatment effects. With aging as an HNC survivor, there may be biological changes that impact treatment outcomes and QoL.[8, 9] Unfortunately, it can be difficult to differentiate age-related effects from treatment-related effects. Consult your medical team with changes that seem unusual. This could be your primary cancer physician, the dental oncology experts, a qualified SLP, a geriatrician offering a comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA), and, always, seek mental health support Neurotoxic effects. This is another common symptom of HNC patients.[10] A peculiar historical irony is that much of chemotherapy was born out of observations in the World Wars I/II, with the observation of nitrogen mustard exposure exhibiting effects on certain cancers [11, 12] . It's not surprising that there are off-target effects and drawbacks to certain chemotherapeutic agents. Neuropathy (tingling and numbness often of your limbs or face) may be one of them. Another neurotoxic symptom of cancer therapy can be cognitive impairment. This brain fog may be long or short lasting. With either symptom, please seek medical help to track the severity. While treatment options are few, research in this area is a priority. Pain management. A good pain management specialist is invaluable. In some cases, opiates may be the best option. This has become more controversial with the opioid crisis. Other options to mitigate pain are an active area of research.[13, 14] In closing, while there have been advances in HNC treatment and cancer, the road ahead for survivors needs to be paved with efforts that improve QoL. The Cancer Neuroscience symposium and special issue in November 2022 that I was part of was an important step in that journey, but the road to pave still lies ahead and must be taken. I remain grateful to my integrated HNC team of dedicated medical and research professionals at the University of Texas M D Anderson Cancer Center. They listened to my wishes and gave me the gift of life… 18 years of watching my daughter grow up. 18 years of travels to see the world. 18 years and counting to speak for many HNC survivors. The authors declare no conflict of interest.

title: ePURE_JSBML: A Tool for Constructing a Deterministic Model of a Reconstituted Escherichia coli Protein Translation System with a User‐Specified Nucleic Acid Sequence
authors: Yoshihiro Shimizu; Naoki Tanimura; Tomoaki Matsuura
abstract: Abstract A protein synthesis system is one of the most important and complex biological networks, which translates DNA‐encoded information into specific functions. Here, ePURE_JSBML, a tool for constructing biologically relevant large‐scale and detailed computational models based on a reconstituted cell‐free protein synthesis system, is presented; the user can specify the mRNA sequence, initial component concentration, and decoding rule. Model construction is based on Systems Biology Markup Language (SBML) using JSBML, a pure Java programming library. The tool generates simulation files, executable with Matlab, that enable a variety of simulation experiments including the synthesis of proteins of a few hundred residues.

title: Noninvasive Evaluation of HepaRG Aggregates during Drug‐Induced Intrahepatic Cholestasis Using Optical Coherence Tomography
authors: Rie Sonoi; Takeshi Yamakawa; N. Nakatani; Masahiko Kokubo; Yoshihisa Hagihara
abstract: Abstract Intrahepatic cholestasis represents a typical manifestation of drug‐induced liver injury. Many researches have been made to understand the drug‐induced cholestasis using human cell based in vitro 3D model. Although noninvasive observation of 3D model will help unveil the hidden mechanism of this phenomenon, there have been few studies using the noninvasive methods. This study has attempted to evaluate the potential of noninvasive optical coherence tomography (OCT) combined with confocal laser scanning microscopy using the aggregates of a differentiated human hepatic cell line. From immunofluorescence staining images, the aggregates during drug‐induced cholestasis are divided into three groups: aggregates of mature phase (type I), immature phase (type II), and death phase (type III). OCT data reveal that different distributions of gray levels of OCT images are observed between heterogeneous (type I and II) and homogeneous cell populations (type III). A threshold based on gray levels of OCT data in each phenotype is determined, and the data can distinguish type III aggregates from the others. The results suggest that OCT data provide valuable information for noninvasively and quantitatively determining the transition of different types of cell population, i.e., from type I and II to type III, in drug‐induced intrahepatic cholestasis processes.

title: Advanced Biosystems becomes Advanced Biology
authors: Kerstin Brachhold
abstract: In order to showcase the expanded scope, we are currently working on several special issues, and I am very happy to already announce the first one: Wilfried Weber and Barbara Di Ventura have agreed to guest-edit a special issue dedicated to “Molecular Optogenetics”. Over the past years, optogenetics has become a versatile tool in life science research. This special issue will be focused on the molecular aspects of this technology from controlling protein activity and signaling pathways to immunological applications. With this we continue our tradition of publishing special issues, such as the December 2020 issue dedicated to the topic of “Extracellular Vesicles” and guest-edited by our editorial board member Ralph Weissleder. This compilation of 12 articles was focused on diagnostic aspects of extracellular vesicles analysis and has been prepared by current and past members of a large exosome consortium in Boston. Furthermore, we have recently streamlined our article types to “Research Articles” and “Reviews”, which may be of any length. However, the scientific contents should justify the length. We will continue to publish “Perspectives” as well as “Comments”. More information on the requirements for each article type can be found on our author guidelines page. The year 2021 will also bring some changes with regards to indexing. I am happy to announce that Clarivate has decided to move the journal from the Emerging Sources Citation Index (ESCI) to the Science Citations Index Expanded (SCIE). This means that we will receive our first impact factor next year. After the inclusion of Advanced Biosystems in MEDLINE (PubMed) in 2020 this represents another milestone for the journal. Advanced Biology's dedicated team of full-time in-house editors is wholeheartedly committed to growing the journal's impact and usefulness for the scientific community with the support of our international editorial advisory board. With new topic areas to cover, we will welcome new editorial board members to help guide us into our future in these growing and productive fields. We are grateful to our authors, readers and editorial board members for their continued support of the journal as we enter our 5th year of publication. I am very excited about our plans for Advanced Biology, and I hope that you will join us on this journey. We are looking forward to receiving your manuscripts from the topic areas mentioned above and related areas and to establishing Advanced Biology as a premium journal for the life sciences. Kerstin Brachhold Editor-in-Chief

title: Reaction Kinetics: Modulating Flow Topology in Microdroplets to Control Reaction Kinetics (Adv. Biology 2/2021)
authors: Shaohua Ma; Haoran Zhao; Edgar A. Galan; Stavroula Balabani
abstract: In article number 2000309, Shaohua Ma and co-workers illustrate the modulation of macromolecular reaction kinetics via flow topology control, instead of chemical approaches. They offer a strategy to design novel reaction systems and understand intracellular reactions.

title: HepaRG Aggregates: Noninvasive Evaluation of HepaRG Aggregates during Drug‐Induced Intrahepatic Cholestasis Using Optical Coherence Tomography (Adv. Biology 2/2021)
authors: Rie Sonoi; Takeshi Yamakawa; N. Nakatani; Masahiko Kokubo; Yoshihisa Hagihara
abstract: In article number 2000198, Rie Sonoi, Yoshihisa Hagihara, and co-workers perform stereoscopic image analyses based on optical coherence tomography (OCT) and confocal laser scanning microscopy using fluorescent probes on aggregates of a differentiated human hepatic cell line. The OCT data analyses non-invasively and quantitatively allow for the determination of the shift of the cell population from heterogeneous (type I and II) to homogeneous (type III) states during drug-induced intrahepatic cholestasis.

title: Host‐Orthogonal Genetic Systems: Development of Host‐Orthogonal Genetic Systems for Synthetic Biology (Adv. Biology 3/2021)
authors: Yang Zhang; Wentao Ding; Zhihui Wang; Huimin Zhao; Shuobo Shi
abstract: The orthogonal genetic system is an artificially engineered system that runs in parallel with the native genetic system. In article number 2000252, Huimin Zhao, Shuobo Shi, and co-workers describe the advances and future challenges in developing such systems. The orthogonal genetic system can be controlled at will and is widely applicable in biosynthesis and thus represents a powerful approach for synthetic biology.

title: Coronavirus Antigens: Efficient Human Cell Coexpression System and Its Application to the Production of Multiple Coronavirus Antigens (Adv. Biology 4/2021)
authors: Chonsaeng Kim; You Kyeong Jeong; Jihyeon Yu; Hye Jin Shin; Keun Bon Ku; Hyung Jin; Jun Hee Han; Sung‐Ah Hong; Bum‐Tae Kim; Seong‐Jun Kim; Jae‐Sung Woo; Sangsu Bae

title: Graphene Quantum Dots: Stress Response and Nutrient Homeostasis in Lettuce (Lactuca sativa) Exposed to Graphene Quantum Dots Are Modulated by Particle Surface Functionalization (Adv. Biology 4/2021)
authors: Peng Zhang; Xinyue Wu; Zhiling Guo; Xiaonan Yang; Xiangang Hu; Iseult Lynch
abstract: In article number 2000778, Peng Zhang and co-workers reveal that graphene quantum dots (GQDs) induce antioxidative damage, alteration of phytohormone levels, and mineral homeostasis, which eventually cause impaired photosynthesis and plant growth. Surface functionalization determines the reactive oxygen species generation and antioxidants oxidation capacity, which leads to different phytotoxicity of GQDs.

title: Antibody‐Antigen Interactions: Design of Smart Antibody Mimetics with Photosensitive Switches (Adv. Biology 5/2021)
authors: Lian He; Peng Tan; Yun Huang; Yubin Zhou
abstract: In article number 2000541, Yubin Zhou, Yun Huang, and co-workers developed innovative optogenetic tools to control antibody-antigen interactions, named Sunbody and Moonbody after the Chinese mythological figures Hou Yi the Sun-shooter and Chang'e the Lady in the Moon, respectively. These photoswitchable modular antibody-like scaffolds contain three allosterically sensitive complementarity-determining regions (symbolized by three rabbits on the moon and three flares on the sun surface), which enable optical control of protein degradation, protein delocalization, immunogenic cell death, transcriptional programming, and CRISPR-aided base editing.

title: Wound Healing: Blue Light‐Operated CRISPR/Cas13b‐Mediated mRNA Knockdown (Lockdown) (Adv. Biology 5/2021)
authors: Tim Blomeier; Patrick Fischbach; Leonie‐Alexa Koch; Jennifer Andres; Miguel Miñambres; Hannes M. Beyer; Matías D. Zurbriggen
abstract: In article number 2000307, Tim Blomeier and co-workers describe the Blue Light-Operated CRISPR/Cas13b-mediated mRNA Knockdown. “Lockdown” introduces optical control of RNA levels utilizing a blue light-dependent switch to induce expression of CRISPR/Cas13b, which mediates sequence-specific knockdown of exo- and endogenous mRNA. Further, they combined the tool with other optogenetic switches for the efficient downregulation of target proteins in mammalian cells.

title: Cell Fragments: Cell Fragment Formation, Migration, and Force Exertion on Extracellular Mimicking Fiber Nanonets (Adv. Biology 6/2021)
authors: Abinash Padhi; Brooke E. Danielsson; Deema S. Alabduljabbar; Ji Wang; Daniel E. Conway; Rakesh K. Kapania; Amrinder S. Nain
abstract: In article number 2000592, Amrinder S. Nain and co-workers report the spontaneous formation of a nuclear cytoplasmic fragments pinching off from cells during migration on extracellular matrix mimicking suspended fibrous networks. Classically studied on flat 2D, fragments on suspended fibers show unique behaviors. Fragments undergo dynamic shape changes capable of extending multiple protrusions and exhibit oscillatory migratory behavior. Contractility measurement of individual fragments can be utilized to devise potential diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. Cover art by Parrish Lee at Fralin Life Sciences Institute, Virginia Tech.

title: EV‐Chips Sensors: Rapid and Electronic Identification and Quantification of Age‐Specific Circulating Exosomes via Biologically Activated Graphene Transistors (Adv. Biology 7/2021)
authors: Reza Hajian; Jonalyn DeCastro; Jonathan Parkinson; Alex Kane; Andres Felipe Romero Camelo; Peichi Peggy Chou; Jielin Yang; Nathan Wong; Ecson Daniel Obando Hernandez; Brett Goldsmith; Irina M. Conboy; Kiana Aran
abstract: In article number 2000594, Kiana Aran and co-coworkers show exosomes binding to a graphene field-effect transistor (gFET), termed EV-chip. The EV-chip enables label-free, rapid, point-of-care identification and quantification of blood-derived exosomes containing biomarkers associated with cancer and other age-related diseases. The sensor is ideal for use in a physician's office or a simple biological laboratory. Image credits: Ella Maru Studio.

title: Integrating Engineering, Automation, and Intelligence to Catalyze the Biomedical Translation of Organoids (Adv. Biology 8/2021)
authors: Shaohua Ma; Haoran Zhao; Edgar A. Galan
abstract: Organoids Biomedical Translation In article 2100535, Ma and co-workers describe their perspective on the engineering elements to promote organoid applications in biomedical translation. “Organoid engineering” comprises the conceptual modules of high-throughput organoid production with reduced variability, automated culturing in a hyper-parallel manner, and intelligent organoid evaluation by learning algorithms to process multi-modality data, and finally, “instrumentation” to catalyze biomedical translation of organoid technologies.

title: The PD‐1 Interactome (Adv. Biology 9/2021)
authors: Qi Wang; Kankana Bardhan; Vassiliki A. Boussiotis; Nikolaos Patsoukis
abstract: Programmed Death-1 In article 2100758, Boussiotis, Patsoukis, Wang, and Bardhan show that Venus-based biomolecular fluorescence complementation detects Programmed Death-1 (PD-1) dimerization by confocal microscopy. HEK-293 cells are transfected with PD-1-VenusYFP-N-terminus and PD-1-VenusYFP-C-terminus together with SHP-2 and either kinase active (top) or kinase inactive (bottom) Fyn. YFP signal (yellow) from VenusYFP structural complementation, indicating PD-1 dimerization at the plasma membrane, is generated only in the presence of kinase active Fyn (red: Rhodamine Phalloidin; blue: DAPI nuclear staining).

title: General Principles for the Detection of Modified Nucleotides in RNA by Specific Reagents (Adv. Biology 10/2021)
authors: Mark Helm; Martina C. Schmidt‐Dengler; Marlies Weber; Yuri Motorin
abstract: Graphene Based Materials In article 2100866, Helm and co-workers review that RNA nucleobases are known to feature intrinsic reactivity towards a number of chemical reagents known from organic chemistry but also occurring in our environment. Some allow to discriminate canonical nucleobases from RNA modifications.

title: Circular Rims2 Deficiency Causes Retinal Degeneration (Adv. Biology 12/2021)
authors: Lanfang Sun; Yue Ma; Yangyang Ji; Zhen Wu; Ya‐Han Wang; Hao Mou; Zi‐Bing Jin
abstract: Circular Rims2 Deficiency In article 2100906, Jin and co-workers discover that a circular RNA, circRims2, is crucial for retinal maintenance and function. Targeted silence of circRims2, but not linear Rims2, leads to significant damages of retinal neurons in the retina. Furthermore, retinal cell apoptosis is mediated by the tumor necrosis factor signaling pathway.

title: An Autonomous Molecular Bioluminescent Reporter (AMBER) for Voltage Imaging in Freely Moving Animals (Adv. Biology 12/2021)
authors: Prasanna Srinivasan; Nicole M Griffin; DhananjayP. Thakur; PradeepM. Joshi; Alex Nguyen‐Le; Sean McCotter; Akshar Jain; Mitra Saeidi; Prajakta Kulkarni; Jaclyn T. Eisdorfer; Joel H. Rothman; Craig Montell; Luke Theogarajan
abstract: Bioluminescent Voltage Indicator Genetically encoded bioluminescent voltage indicators enable the non-invasive imaging of neural activity without the need for external illumination enabling truly wireless operation. However, the need for external substrate addition has limited the use of this approach. In article 2100842, Srinivasan, Theogarajan and co-workers describe an autonomous molecular bioluminescent reporter (AMBER), which overcomes this limitation and demonstrates it by imaging the voltage activity in freely moving C. elegans.

abstract: In article number 2000223, Silvia Ronchi, Michele Fiscella, and co-workers show neurons plated on a high-density microelectrode array. The small electrode size and the tight spacing between the 26 400 electrodes enable functional extracellular electrophysiological characterization of neurons across scales, from subcellular-resolution features, like axons and dendrites, through individual neuronal cells to entire networks. Image credits: M. Oeggerli

abstract: Angiogenic Sprouting Dynamics In article 2101080, Young and co-workers examinate the angiogenic sprouts (orange) extend from a 3D endothelial lumen on the left towards a fibroblast spheroid (blue) on the right, all in a microfluidic cell culture system. Triangular microposts (dark triangles) separate the central microchannel containing the fibroblast spheroid from the left microchannel containing the endothelial lumen. The sprouts are observed to surround the spheroid.

abstract: The production of biomolecules that require human-specific lipid environments is extremely useful for basic research and medical applications. In article number 2000154, Seong-Jun Kim, Jae-Sung Woo, Sangsu Bae, and co-workers integrate multiple proteins or virus antigens into defined transcriptional hotspots in the human genome via a homology-independent targeted insertion method using CRISPR nucleases. This system is similar to a production pipeline of biomolecules in a factory controlled by CRISPR.

authors: No authors
abstract: In article number 2000024, Fuyin Zheng, Yubo Fan, Ming Dao, and co-workers show that organoids and organ-on-a-chip are synergistic engineering approaches linking with vascularization and innervation to faithfully reconstitute in vitro organ-level structures and functions with high structural fidelity, cellular consistency, environmental control ability, integration as well as through-put. This review also detail current achievements, barriers, and future prospects of these promising combinations by incorporating organoids, organ-a-on-chip, 3D printing, and numerical simulation toward patient-specific disease-on-a-chip and human-on-a-chip.
